narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the semantics of writing about music from several different lenses: the profile, the argumentative essay, the academic paper, and the review.
music reviews, profiles, cultural critique/analysis, research

- Writing! (Who would have thought.) Specifically, writing as a tool to EVOKE (that is the big theme of this class). I'd say that a lot of Yale writing classes focus on clarity (which is good), but this class was refreshingly more focused on the quality of evocation.
- A new way of listening to music - as soon as you have to write about music, you are forced to pay attention to it in a way that is much unlike passive listening 
- A major appreciation for the art of creative nonfiction

I got experience writing a music review, journalistic profile, persuasive essay, and research paper, as well as a significantly broadened perspective on music and music history through the art of evoking music with words and reading model essays about it. I also improved at constructive critiques and critical thinking through our workshops and discussions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class is very fun and engaging. I genuinely think that almost anyone would find the readings interesting and class discussions were always fun with Professor Sexton. The only complaint I had about this course was that on some random Thursday there was a whole book assigned and we weren't warned before Tuesdays class that we were going to be reading the whole book. And like of course, no one actually finished this book. I mean the part of it I read was super interesting and I definitely will finish this summer on my own time but I really would have liked if we had spent longer talking about it or only had to read part of it.
great course great professor. excellent job given the pandemic.

Strengths:
- My favorite part of this course was the evocation exercises (we would listen to a song at the start of the class every Tuesday and have to immediately respond to it in a paragraph or two to evoke it -- very interesting way of learning how to write quickly and concisely
- If you love music, none of the homework will feel like homework
- The course is really flexible in writing about things that interest you
- Prof Sexton leaves so much feedback on your essays - super nice!!!

Weaknesses:
- Almost wanted to do more essay to have a bit more practice
- There is rather randomly a whole book assigned in the middle of the course that is very interesting but no one had time to fully read
- Sometimes the workshops would be a bit too flattery focused than constructive
We covered an amazing breadth of music and perspectives.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The workshops were really good for engagement and fostering a community among the class. I can only imagine how fun this all would have been in person!
really good job with the music evocation exercises. those were always fun and I didn't feel like I missed too much despite being virtual.
The predictable structure of workshops, in-class writing, and other elements helped the course operate very successfully over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! If you are even a little interested in music (you don't need to be a musician or anything) I would highly recommend taking this course. All the papers were a billion times more fun to write than your standard academic paper, and plus we got to listen to some fun tunes.
Yes absolutely. Adam is a gem and gives very meaningful comments both in class and on your papers. Great way to talk and write about music.
If you love music, take this class!!!!!! It will be a joy in your day.
If you have any interest in writing and music, you'll probably enjoy writing about music!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
